iati-activity.iati-identifier: US-EIN-521257057-NDC Partnership Support Unit and CAEP/TAF

title.narrative: NDC Partnership Support Unit and CAEP - BEIS

description.narrative: The NDC Partnership (the Partnership) is a global coalition of countries and institutions collaborating to drive transformational climate action while enhancing sustainable development. The Partnership is working directly with developing country governments, mobilizing resources and expertise to support and accelerate their Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) implementation and increased ambition in updated NDC around the worlds. The Partnership is recognized as a neutral broker among stakeholders and a trusted partner, evidencing a strong governance structure, clear theory of change, and transparent strategy. Guided by a Steering Committee, the Partnership is comprised of developed and developing nations and international institutions and led by Co-Chairs from the Republic of Costa Rica and the Kingdom of the Netherlands. A Support Unit, which facilitates the work of the Partnership, has grown and consolidated to support its ambitious vision. As more governments seek support for turning NDCs into action, membership continues to grow considerably.

The NDC Partnership’s Climate Action Enhancement Package (CAEP) is a new offering of the Partnership designed to be a targeted, demand-driven, and impact-focused fast-track initiative to deliver support for implementing and enhancing NDCs to set countries up for success in achieving raised ambition. It will allow countries to address the challenges of the first generation of NDCs by providing support for the development and implementation of evidence-based, high-quality NDCs with broad ownership from society and government. CAEP has two core elements: Leveraging new and existing support for NDC implementation and updating from member countries and institutions; Establishing a Technical Assistance Fund (TAF) for fast deployment of additional resources beyond those available through existing initiatives; and Partnership members able to quickly deploy technical and financial support will have the first option to respond to country requests under CAEP. Remaining gaps in support can then be covered by members of the Partnership with the required expertise but without available resources, by accessing the TAF. The TAF is a financial delivery instrument of CAEP. It is a pooled funding mechanism that will receive contributions from multiple development partners and allocate resources to multiple implementing partners in response to NDC enhancement requests under CAEP.

participating-org.narrative: UK - Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS)

receiver-org.receiver-activity-id: US-EIN-521257057-NDC Partnership Support Unit and CAEP/TAF

title.narrative: Member countries that submit new NDC in 2020 after receiving CAEP support under Objective 1 that enhance their NDCs by 2020

description.narrative: 65 countries are committed to enhancing their NDCs with support from more than 35 partners through the Climate Action Enhancement Package (CAEP). More than 40 of the Partnership’s institutional and associate members have committed to deliver NDC enhancement support to 65 countries through the common framework of CAEP, with more than 20 of them accessing resources from TAF. Seven partners have contributed to TAF and CAEP.

title.narrative: Percentage of Member countries that submit new NDC in 2020 after receiving CAEP support under Objective 1 that enhance their NDCs by 2020

description.narrative: A total of 67 countries are receiving CAEP support. Of the 18 countries that submitted an updated or new NDC by December 2020 with CAEP support, 100% increased their adaptation or mitigation ambition. Of the 49 remaining countries receiving CAEP support, 47 are on track to submit enhanced NDCs before COP26 .

title.narrative: Member countries with CAEP support reporting more effective NDC implementation to achieve mitigation and adaptation targets due to Partnership support

description.narrative: 65 countries are committed to enhancing their NDCs with support from more than 35 partners through the Climate Action Enhancement Package (CAEP). More than 40 of the Partnership’s institutional and associate members have committed to deliver NDC enhancement support to 65 countries through the common framework of CAEP, with more than 20 of them accessing resources from TAF. Seven partners have contributed to TAF and CAEP.

title.narrative: Percentage of member countries with CAEP support reporting more effective NDC implementation to achieve mitigation and adaptation targets due to Partnership support

description.narrative: Developing country members also reported greater effectiveness both in the NDC updating process and in NDC implementation. According to the 2021 Member Survey, 93% of country respondents who had received CAEP support, stated that their country’s NDC updating process was more effective, and 86% indicated more effective NDC implementation overall.

title.narrative: 3.3. Countries access knowledge resources, capacity building support initiatives, and cross-country learning related to NDC implementation through the Partnership Knowledge Portal, peer to peer exchanges, and outreach materials.

comment.narrative: The communications team has tested platform-specific engagement tools and will expand and make greater use of these tools to drive growth and engagement. Both Twitter and LinkedIn offer the greatest potential for growth and will be primarily targeted.

description.narrative: This indicator reflects the aggregate number of KPIs being supported by members (rather than outputs) as implementing partners provide support and respond to country requests at this activity level. This indicator will need to be altered in the future to reflect this clarification.

Impact 1.1: Countries successfully reduce emissions, improve climate resilience, and advance sustainable development with strong international support consistent with the achievement of the Paris Agreement and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development

3.1: Enhanced country engagement, coordination across government agencies and country stakeholders, and country ownershipof climate action and sustainable development.
3.1.6a Number of gender analyses (basic information vs. in-depth) included in country engagement process through RSAs

description.narrative: Basic information: gender equality section of the RSA was filled out in a complete manner; In-depth information: analysis done with the support from a member

title.narrative: 3.1.3 Number of member countries with established or strengthened NDC coordination mechanisms

description.narrative: For better measurability, this indicator has been revised from: number of member countries with NDCs developed and/or implemented through regular (at least annually) multi-stakeholder engagement processes, disaggregated by engagement with: a) multiple ministries, including planning, finance, and relevant sectoral ministries; b)government agencies responsible for different underrepresented groups, including on gender equality, indigenous peoples, and others, and respective focal points within sectors/ministries; and c) non-state actors, private sector, civil society (including women’s organizations and other underrepresented groups). The target for this KPI was 38 before the Work Program Addendum.

title.narrative: 3.1.3.a Percentage of Partnership Plans developed and periodically assessed with involvement of national gender agency and stakeholders

description.narrative: For this indicator, this percentage represents the share of countries that conducted two or more NDC consultations with gender stakeholders.

title.narrative: 3.1.4 Percentage of government focal points and/or facilitators reporting improved coordination and harmonization of government agency systems, strategies and responses in support of NDC implementation

description.narrative: This data comes from a member survey conducted in January-February 2020 as part of the Partnership’s Mid-Term Review. In response to the survey question asking respondents whether they felt there was improved coordination between government and sectors/country stakeholders over the last three years, 48 percent of respondents reported improved coordination. (Note: There was an18percentmember response rate to the overall survey.)

title.narrative: 3.1.2.a Percentage of Partnership Plans with sex disaggregated KPIs (data)

description.narrative: This indicator accounts for the percentage of Partnership Plans which include references to gender, sex, or male to female comparisons within output-level indicators. This indicator has been refined to show the extent to which Partnership Plans have included sex-disaggregated data and gender indicators across four levels: Level 1 (L1): Absence of gender indicators; Level 2 (L2):includes indicators for participation at events or a gender-specific indicator; Level 3(L3):includes indicators related to beneficiaries and social changes; and Level 4(L4): includes indicators which are paired with M&E systems. For this indicator, we have aggregated levels 2 through 4, which means that at least one sex-disaggregated indicator or a call for sex-disaggregated data was included in the Partnership Plan.

title.narrative: 3.1.2 Number of Partnership Plans or documents confirming requests for support endorsed by government nd under implementation
3.1.8 In-Country stop and reflect exercise conducted and results communicated to the government Focal Points and relevant Partners for follow up

description.narrative: The target for this KPI was 23 before the Work Program Addendum.

comment.narrative: A virtual stop and reflect exercise is proposed towards the end of the year. •Tie Stop and Reflect exercises to other national events or planning exercises to reduce the administrative or time burden on the countries.
